grade-calculator.description: Calculating grade point average (GPA) based on grades and credits

errors.title: Data errors
errors.courseNameRequired: Enter the name of the item
errors.invalidCredits: The number of credits must be greater than 0

seo.title: Online grade calculator (GPA) - GPA calculation | Calc1.ru
seo.description: Free online grade point average (GPA) calculator to calculate GPA based on grades and credits. Supports 5-point, 4-point (GPA), 100-point and letter grading systems. Helps you plan your studies.
seo.keywords: grade calculator, GPA calculator, GPA calculation, GPA online, GPA calculator, GPA calculation, weighted average, student grade calculator, GPA calculator, grade calculator, diploma GPA, certificate GPA calculation, grades calculator with credits, GPA including credits, weighted GPA, unweighted GPA, average calculation admission score, university GPA, school grade calculator

overview.title: Online grade calculator (GPA)
overview.content: The online grade point average (GPA) calculator will help you calculate your grade point average based on course grades and number of credits (hours). Supports various grading systems: 5-point (Russia), 4-point (GPA, USA), 100-point (percentage) and letter (A-F).
overview.additionalContent: GPA (Grade Point Average) is the average grade point average, which is calculated as a weighted average of grades taking into account the credits (hours) of each subject. Formula: GPA = Sum (Grade × Credits) / Sum of Credits. The more credits a subject has, the greater its impact on your overall GPA.

calculationExamples.title: GPA calculation examples
calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculating average scores for various situations:

example1.title: Example 1: 5-point system, 4 items
example1.input:
Mathematics: 5 (3 credits)
Physics: 4 (4 credits)
Chemistry: 5 (2 credits)
History: 4 (2 credits)
example1.note: A GPA above 4.0 is considered an excellent result

example2.title: Example 2: 4-point system (GPA), 5 subjects
example2.input:
Math: 4.0 (3 credits)
Physics: 3.7 (4 credits)
Chemistry: 3.0 (3 credits)
English: 3.3 (2 credits)
History: 2.7 (3 credits)
example2.note: GPA 3.0-3.5 is considered a good result

example3.title: Example 3: Letter system, 6 items
example3.input:
Math: A (4 credits)
Physics: A (4 credits)
Chemistry: B (3 credits)
English: A (3 credits)
History: B (2 credits)
Art: A (2 credits)
example3.note: Predominantly A grades give a high GPA

example4.title: Example 4: Impact of Credits on GPA
example4.description: Two students with the same grades but different credits
example4.input:
Student 1:
Mathematics: 5 (6 credits)
Physics: 4 (2 credits)

Student 2:
Mathematics: 5 (2 credits)
Physics: 4 (6 credits)
example4.note: Subjects with more credits have a greater impact on GPA

example5.title: Example 5: 100-point system
example5.input:
Mathematics: 95% (4 credits)
Physics: 87% (4 credits)
Chemistry: 78% (3 credits)
History: 92% (2 credits)
example5.note: Percentage grades are converted to GPA using the standard scale

example6.title: Example 6: Improving GPA
example6.description: Calculation of required grades to improve GPA
example6.input:
Current GPA: 3.2 (45 credits)
New items: 15 credits
Desired GPA: 3.5
example6.calculation:
Current points = 3.2 × 45 = 144
Needed for GPA 3.5 = 3.5 × 60 = 210
Need to dial = 210 - 144 = 66
Average score in new subjects = 66 / 15 = 4.4
example6.result: Requires a 4.4 GPA in new courses
example6.note: To increase your GPA you need to get high grades in subjects with a large number of credits

calculation.title: How is GPA calculated?
calculation.content: Calculation of GPA (Grade Point Average) includes several stages to determine the average grade point average, taking into account the credits (hours) of each subject.
calculation.formula: GPA = Sum (Grade × Credits) / Sum of Credits
calculation.weighted: The weighted average takes into account the number of credits (hours) of each subject
calculation.credits: Credits (hours) show the weight of a subject in the overall grade
calculation.conversion: Different rating systems are converted into a single scale for comparison

steps.credits: Indication of the number of credits (hours) for each subject

advantages.title: Benefits of the Grading Calculator
advantages.content: Using a grade calculator provides many benefits: accurate GPA calculation, study planning, progress tracking.

tips.title: Tips for calculating GPA
tips.content: To get an accurate result, follow our recommendations when calculating GPA.
tips.credits: Indicate the exact number of credits (hours) for each subject - this is critical for correct calculation
tips.system: Choose the right grading system for your institution
tips.allGrades: Include all subjects to obtain an accurate GPA
tips.regular: Regularly recalculate your GPA when you receive new grades

faqItems.q: What is GPA?
faqItems.a: GPA (Grade Point Average) is the average grade point average, which is calculated as a weighted average of grades taking into account the credits (hours) of each subject. GPA shows a student's overall academic performance.

faqItems.q: How to calculate GPA?
faqItems.a: GPA = Sum (Grade × Credits) / Sum of Credits. For example, Mathematics 5 (3 credits), Physics 4 (4 credits): GPA = (5×3 + 4×4) / (3+4) = 31/7 = 4.43.

faqItems.q: What is the difference between weighted and unweighted GPA?
faqItems.a: Weighted GPA takes into account the number of credits (hours) of each subject. An unweighted GPA is simply the arithmetic average of all grades. Weighted GPA is more accurate.

faqItems.q: What are GPA credits?
faqItems.a: Credits (or hours) are a unit of measurement for the amount of academic work in a subject. Courses with more credits have a greater impact on your overall GPA.

faqItems.q: How to convert grades from 5-point system to GPA?
faqItems.a: 5→4.0, 4→3.0, 3→2.0, 2→0.0. However, the exact conversion depends on the requirements of the particular school or system.

faqItems.q: How to convert percentage grades to GPA?
How to convert letter grades to GPA?
Do credits affect GPA?
faqItems.a: Yes, credits have a significant impact on GPA. A course with more credits carries more weight in the GPA calculation.

faqItems.q: What GPA is considered good?
faqItems.a: GPA 3.0-3.5 is considered good, 3.5-4.0 - excellent. In Russia, 4.0-4.5 out of 5.0 is considered a good result.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to improve GPA?
faqItems.a: Yes, your GPA can be improved by getting high grades in new courses, especially those with more credits. The more new loans, the greater the impact on GPA.

faqItems.q: How to calculate what GPA is needed to achieve a goal?
faqItems.a: If current GPA = G1 (C1 credits), desired GPA = G2, new subjects = C2 credits, then desired GPA in new subjects = (G2×(C1+C2) - G1×C1) / C2.

faqItems.q: Does retaking affect GPA?
faqItems.a: Depends on the policy of the educational institution. In some cases, the new score replaces the old one, in others, both scores are taken into account. Check with your school for rules.

faqItems.q: How to calculate GPA for a semester?
faqItems.a: Use only grades and credits from the current semester. Semester GPA = Sum (Grade × Semester Credits) / Semester Credit Sum.

faqItems.q: How to calculate overall GPA?
faqItems.a: Use all grades and credits for the entire period of study. Overall GPA = Sum (Grade × Credits of all subjects) / Sum of all credits.

faqItems.q: What is cumulative GPA?
faqItems.a: Cumulative GPA is the overall average score for the entire period of study, including all semesters and years. This is the most comprehensive indicator of academic performance.

faqItems.q: How to calculate GPA for university admission?
faqItems.a: Admission usually requires a cumulative GPA for the entire period of study at school or college. Make sure you are using the correct grading system at your target university.

faqItems.q: Does GPA affect scholarship?
faqItems.a: Yes, in many educational institutions, GPA affects scholarships. Typically a GPA above a certain threshold is required (for example, 3.5 or 4.0).

faqItems.q: How to calculate GPA taking into account pass/fail?
faqItems.a: Courses with a pass/fail system are usually not counted toward the GPA or are counted as a passing grade. Check with your school for rules.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to have a GPA above 4.0?
faqItems.a: In the standard 4-point system, the maximum is 4.0. However, in some weighted GPA systems, additional points may be awarded for difficult courses, allowing you to achieve a GPA above 4.0.

faqItems.q: How to calculate GPA for a diploma?
faqItems.a: Use all grades and credits from all courses included in the diploma. Diploma GPA = Sum (Grade × Credits) / Sum of credits of all diploma subjects.

faqItems.q: Does GPA affect employment?
faqItems.a: In some industries (especially graduates), employers may consider GPA when selecting candidates. However, experience and skills are often more important than GPA.

faqItems.q: How to calculate GPA?
faqItems.a: The average score of the certificate is calculated as the arithmetic mean of all grades (excluding credits). Average score = Sum of marks / Number of subjects.

faqItems.q: What should I do if I don’t remember the number of credits?
faqItems.a: Contact your academic department or dean's office for information about credits. If credits are unknown, the arithmetic average (unweighted GPA) can be used, but this will be less accurate.

faqItems.q: How to calculate GPA for master's degree?
faqItems.a: Master's GPA is calculated in the same way, but only grades and credits from the master's program are taken into account. Some programs require a minimum GPA for admission (usually 3.0-3.5).

faqItems.q: Does GPA affect your ability to get into graduate school?
faqItems.a: Yes, a high GPA (usually 3.5-4.0 or higher) is often required for admission to graduate school. GPA shows academic performance and ability for scientific work.

faqItems.q: How to calculate GPA taking into account exams and tests?
faqItems.a: Typically, only exam grades (numeric grades) are taken into account in GPA, and credits are not counted or counted as a passing grade. Check with your school for rules.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to calculate GPA online?
faqItems.a: Yes, our GPA calculator allows you to calculate your GPA online. Simply enter your grades and credits and the calculator will automatically calculate your GPA.

faqItems.q: How often should GPA be recalculated?
faqItems.a: It is recommended to recalculate your GPA after each new grade is received or after the end of each semester. This will help you track your progress and plan your studies.

faqItems.q: What is a quality score in GPA?
faqItems.a: Qualitative score is the number of points (Grade × Credits) accumulated in all subjects. The qualitative score is used to calculate GPA.

faqItems.q: How to calculate GPA for several years of study?
faqItems.a: Use all grades and credits from all years of study. Overall GPA = Sum (Grade × Credits for all years) / Sum of credits for all years.

faqItems.q: Does GPA affect group ranking?
faqItems.a: Yes, many schools rank students by GPA. Students with a high GPA usually rank higher in rankings.

faqItems.q: How to calculate GPA for online courses?
faqItems.a: GPA for online courses is calculated in the same way as for regular courses. Grades and credits (hours) of online courses are taken into account.

faqItems.q: What is the minimum GPA for graduation?
faqItems.a: The minimum GPA for graduation varies by institution. Typically a GPA of at least 2.0 (4-point system) or 3.0 (5-point system) is required.

faqItems.q: How to calculate GPA for transfer students?
faqItems.a: When transferring, GPA is calculated only on the basis of grades obtained at the new educational institution. Grades from a previous institution usually do not carry over to the GPA of a new one.
